case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 495, 539 and 540, 684, 694, 717 and 857 of 1966

facts.text: Appeals are Civil Appeals Nos. 495, 539 and 540, 684, 694, 717 and 857 of 1966 by special leave from Madras High Court judgments dated September 23, 1963, April 29, 1963, July 29, 1964, March 13, 1964, June 22, 1964 and June 24, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 495, 539 and 540, 684, 694, 717 and 857 of 1966. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated September 23, 1963, April 29, 1963, July 29, 1964, March 13, 1964, June 22, 1964 and June 24, 1964 of the Madras High Court in Tax Cases Nos. 246 of 1962  Revision No. 96  202 and 203 of 1961, 67 of 1963  Appeal No. 6 , 43 of 1964  Revision No. 17 , 12 of 1963  Appeal No. 2  and 112 of 1964  Revision No. 64  respectively.

facts.text: Appeal No. 495 of 1966 is from judgment of Madras High Court dated September 23, 1963 in Tax Case No. 246 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 495 of 1966 The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J. This appeal is brought, by special leave,from the judgment of the Madras High Court dated September 23, 1963, in Tax Case No. 246 of 1962.

facts.text: Respondent was a Beedi manufacturer in Gudiyattam, Madras State.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who was a Beedi manufacturer in Gudiyattam, Madras State was assessed to sales tax on a taxable turnover of Rs. 1,73,502/11/10 for the assessment year 1955-56 by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer.

facts.text: Respondent assessed to sales tax on turnover of Rs. 1,73,502/11/10 for assessment year 1955-56 by Deputy Commercial Tax Officer on February 15, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who was a Beedi manufacturer in Gudiyattam, Madras State was assessed to sales tax on a taxable turnover of Rs. 1,73,502/11/10 for the assessment year 1955-56 by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer. Against this order of assessment dated February 15, 1957 the respondent appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Salem

facts.text: Respondent appealed assessment order to Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Salem, disputing inclusion of Rs. 1,11,299 as second purchases or purchases outside Madras State.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of assessment dated February 15, 1957 the respondent appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Salem disputing the inclusion of a sum of Rs. 1, 1 1,299 - and odd on the ground that the said amount represented either second purchases or purchases made outside the State of Madras.

facts.text: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959 was passed repealing 1939 Act, appeal disposed under 1959 Act.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the appeal the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959 was passed and the earlier Act of 1939 was repealed and by force of the provisions in the 1959 Act, the appeal was finally disposed of by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Salem.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner order dated July 2, 1960 held excise duty not part of purchase turnover, enhanced assessment by including Rs. 1,15,406/14/9 as inter-State purchases from April 1, 1955 to September 5, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated July 2, 1960, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the excise duty paid by the respondent companyld number form part of his purchase turnover but in purported exercise of his powers under the new Act enhanced the assessment of the turnover by including a gum of Rs. 1,15,406/14/9 as inter- State purchases from April 1, 1955 to September 5, 1955.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent took the matter in further appeal to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Appellant filed petitions before Tribunal to enhance assessment by Rs. 3,66,213/12/- as sales of manufactured beedies to non-resident buyers May 12, 1955 to September 5, 1955, goods in state at time of contract.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also filed petitions before the Tribunal for enhancement of the assessment by Rs. 3,66,213/12/- on the ground that the amount represented sales of manufactured beedies to number- resident buyers during the period May 12, 1955 to September 5, 1955 and that the goods, in question were within the territory of the State at the time the companytract of sale in respect thereof was made.

facts.text: Tribunal claimed sales taxable under Explanation 2 to s.2(h) of 1939 Act due to Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the appellant that the sales were taxable by virtue of Explanation  2  to s. 2 h  of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 in view of the lifting of the ban on the levy of tax on inter-State sales by the Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956  Central Act VII of 1956 , hereinafter called the Validation Act,

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal order dated July 13, 1962 allowed enhancement petition, rejected respondent's agency sales contention, remanded second purchases/outside purchases.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated July 13, 1962 the Appellate Tribunal allowed the petition for enhancement and rejected the companytention of the respondent that the sales were agency sales through Commission Agents. As regards the alleged second purchases or outside purchases of raw tobacco, the Appellate Tribunal remanded the case to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition in Madras High Court under s.38 of 1959 Act against Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the Appellate Tribunal the respondent filed a petition in the High Court, of Madras under s. 38 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1959.

facts.text: Madras High Court order dated September 23, 1963 held inclusion of Rs. 1,15,406/14/9 inter-State purchases bad, no jurisdiction; Rs. 3,66,213/12/- not taxable as Explanation sales under Art. 286(1), delivered outside state for consumption.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated September 23, 1963 the High Court held  1  that the inclusion of the inter-State purchases from April 1, 1955 to September 5, 1955 of Rs. 1,15,406/14/9. was bad as the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had numberjurisdiction to include that turnover  2  that the turnover of Rs. 3,66,213/12/- included by the Appellate Tribunal companyld number be brought to tax as the beedies, which were the subject of the relevant sales, were delivered outside the State for purposes of companysumption and as the sales therefore companystituted Explanation sales under Art. 286 1  of the Constitution as it stood prior to the Sixth Amendment and companysequently the Madras State had numberjurisdiction to tax the said sales.

facts.text: State of Madras appealed to Supreme Court aggrieved by High Court decision on taxability of inter-State sales prior to September 6, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by that part of the decision of the Madras High Court on the question of taxability of the said transactions of inter- State sales effected prior to September 6, 1955, the State of Madras has brought the present appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Madras State had no jurisdiction to levy sales tax on alleged Explanation sales by respondent April 1 to September 5, 1955 under Explanation 2 to s.2(h) of 1939 Act.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore in the present case that the goods sold and delivered outside the State during the period from April, 1955 to September, 1955 were number liable to tax under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 and the taxing authorities had numberjurisdiction to include Rs. 3,66,213/12/- in the turnover of the respondent.

facts.text: Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956 (Central Act VII of 1956) validated state taxes on inter-State sales from April 1, 1951 to September 6, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: By this Act therefore the Parliament removed the ban companytained in Art. 286 2  of the Constitution retrospectively but limited only to the period between April 1, 1951 and September 6, 1955. All transactions of sale, even though the were inter-State sales companyld for that period be lawfully charged to tax.

facts.text: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar judgment delivered September 6, 1955 held states cannot tax inter-State sales until Parliament provides otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of this Court in The Bengal Immunity Companys 1  case was delivered on September 6, 1955. The President then issued the Sales Tax Laws Validation Ordi- nance, 1956, on January 30, 1956, the provisions of which were later embodied in the Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956.

facts.text: High Court relied on affidavits filed by respondent, no objection by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellant did number raise any objection before the High Court when the affidavits were taken into evidence. Having preferred numberobjection before the High Court it is number number open to the appellant to gay that the High Court acted illegally in taking those affidavits in evidence.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal No. 495 of 1966, no costs.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons assigned we hold that this appeal has numbermerit and must be dismissed. In the circumstances of the case we do number propose to make any order as to companyts.

facts.text: Other appeals 539,540,684,694,717,857 of 1966 dismissed for same reasons as CA 495, no authority to tax Explanation sales under Art. 286(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The main question to be companysidered in these appeals is whe- ther, after the enactment of the Validation Act, Madras State had the companystitutional power to tax Explanation sales falling under Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution i.e., where goods were delivered for companysumption outside the State and whether the ban under Art. 296 1  a  was an independent ban and whether it companyld be removed by Parliamentary legislation under Art. 286 2 .

facts.text: In CA 717/1966, respondent entitled to costs as ordered on July 29, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of the case we do number propose to make any order as to companyts except in C A. 71.7 of 1966, In that appeal, the respondent will be entitled to companyts as already ordered on 29th July 1965.

issues.text: whether the Madras State had jurisdiction to levy sales tax on the alleged Explanation sales by the respondent during the period between April 1, 1955 to September 5, 1955 by virtue of Explanation 2 to s. 2 h of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939

anchor.surface_text: The question presented for consideration in this appeal is whether the Madras State had jurisdiction to levy sales tax on the alleged Explanation sales by the respondent during the period between April 1, 1955 to September 5, 1955 by virtue of Explanation  2  to s. 2 h

arguments.claim: Under pre-Constitution territorial nexus, Provinces could tax sales with nexus to territory

anchor.surface_text: Under the Government of India Act, 1935, it was open to every Provincial Legislature to enact legislation authorising the levy of tax on sale of goods in respect of transactions whether within or outside the Province, provided the Province had a territorial nexus with one or more elements constituting the sale.

arguments.claim: Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) replaced territorial nexus with delivery for consumption test

anchor.surface_text: The test of sufficient territorial nexus was thus replaced by a simpler and more easily workable testAre the goods actually delivered in the taxing State, as a direct result of a sale or purchase, for the purpose of consumption therein?

arguments.court_reasoning: Citing United Motors; avoids multiple taxation

holdings.text: Madras State had no jurisdiction to levy sales tax on Explanation sales by respondent during April 1 to September 5, 1955 under Explanation 2 to s.2(h) of Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 even after Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore in the present case that the goods sold and delivered outside the State during the period from April, 1955 to September, 1955 were number liable to tax under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 and the taxing authorities had numberjurisdiction to include Rs. 3,66,213/12/- in the turnover of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validation Act lifts only ban under Art. 286(2); bans under Art. 286(1)(a) on Explanation sales (delivery outside state for consumption) independent and cumulative; follows Bengal Immunity and United Motors

holdings.text: Operative provisions of Art. 286 (cl.1(a),1(b),2,3) deal with different topics; Explanation to 1(a) not extendable to cl.2

anchor.surface_text: In The Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd., v. The State of Bihar and Others 1 , it was held by this Court that the operative provisions of the several parts of Art. 286, namely el.  1  a , el.  1  b , el.  2  and el.  3 , are intended to deal with different topics and one cannot be projected or read into another,

precedents.citation: The Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd., v. The State of Bihar and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: The Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd., v. The State of Bihar and Others 1

precedents.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: operative provisions of the several parts of Art. 286 are intended to deal with different topics and one cannot be projected or read into another; Explanation in cl. 1(a) cannot be extended to cl. 2; no State may impose tax on inter-State sales until Parliament provides otherwise
precedents.cited_holding: until the Parliament by law made in exercise of the powers vested in it by cl. 2 of Art. 286 provides otherwise, no State may impose or authorise the imposition of any tax on sales or purchases of goods when such sales or purchases take place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce

precedents.citation: Messrs Ashok Leyland Ltd. v. The State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Messrs Ashok Leyland Ltd. v. The State of Madras 1

precedents.case_name: Ashok Leyland Ltd. v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: argument based on second Explanation to s.2(h) of Madras Act

precedents.citation: The State of Bombay v. The United Motors  India  Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay v. The United Motors  India  Ltd. 1

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Explanation to Art. 286(1) provides by legal fiction that sale takes place in State of actual delivery for consumption notwithstanding property passed elsewhere
precedents.cited_holding: It provides by means of a legal fiction that the State in which the goods sold or purchased are actually delivered for consumption therein is the State in which the sale or purchase is to be considered to have taken place, notwithstanding the property in such goods passed in another State.

precedents.citation: Shree Bajrang Jute Mills Ltd. v. State of Andhra Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: Shree Bajrang Jute Mills Ltd. v. State of Andhra Pradesh 1

precedents.case_name: Shree Bajrang Jute Mills Ltd. v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: principle that only State of delivery-cum-consumption can tax Explanation sales; physical delivery required
precedents.cited_holding: if the goods were delivered pursuant to the contracts of sale outside the State for consumption there, taxing State has no right to tax by virtue of Art. 286(1)(a) read with Explanation

precedents.citation: Singareni Collieries Co. Ltd. v. State of Andhra Pradesh 2

anchor.surface_text: Singareni Collieries Co. Ltd. v. State of Andhra Pradesh 2

precedents.case_name: Singareni Collieries Co. Ltd. v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: sales of coal delivered outside State for consumption there cannot be taxed; Explanation deems sale in State of delivery regardless of where property passes
